update.description:
Based on a user option, --output-label, the bed file will output either the superlabel only (default), the sublabel only, or both concatenated with a period. The tests produce the same result for me with and without these changes.

Update 2014-06-20
This is only done with the viterbi task for now, posterior will output superlabels only, and raise error if trying to do posterior and also trying to print sublabels. touchstone files are updated as a result of output_seg argument being passed, and viterbi regex filter which catches subseg and seg lines. Tests working now.
update.title: Code to output sublabels

content.raw: Nothing needs to be resubmitted. When all changes have been submitted and everything seems in order I'll merge it in.
content.html: Nothing needs to be resubmitted. When all changes have been submitted and everything seems in order I'll merge it in.

content.raw: The only thing I'd mention here is that people using segway (and reading the documents) may not be familiar with Python programming. I would be hesitant to mention python string formatting and simply state that it will be the segment and the subsegment seperated by a '.' and possibly give an example ( e.g "22.3" )
content.html: The only thing I'd mention here is that people using segway (and reading the documents) may not be familiar with Python programming. I would be hesitant to mention python string formatting and simply state that it will be the segment and the subsegment seperated by a '.' and possibly give an example ( e.g "22.3" )

content.raw: You mean why do we need both seg and subseg output from gmtk in that case? It was to differentiate later between 2 coordinates with the same sublabel but different superlabels, like 0.1 and 1.1, even though just the sublabel is being printed I thought that was the desired behavior.
content.html: You mean why do we need both seg and subseg output from gmtk in that case? It was to differentiate later between 2 coordinates with the same sublabel but different superlabels, like 0.1 and 1.1, even though just the sublabel is being printed I thought that was the desired behavior.

content.raw: Why do you need it when `output_label == "subseg"`?
content.html: Why do you need it when output_label == "subseg"?

content.raw: Format this line according to PEP 8: http://legacy.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0008/#pet-peeves
content.html: Format this line according to PEP 8: http://legacy.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0008/#pet-peeves

content.raw:
For me, this was a little confusing at first. 

A few considerations:

- There's no indication at this point that the superlabels are in fact the labels for the colors themeselves and I had to think about it for a while. Perhaps a comment?
- Or maybe it would make a little more sense if the list comprehension included the get_label_color call inside. Or perhaps just renaming color_labels to something like 'superlabels'.
content.html:
For me, this was a little confusing at first.

A few considerations:

  • There's no indication at this point that the superlabels are in fact the labels for the colors themeselves and I had to think about it for a while. Perhaps a comment?
  • Or maybe it would make a little more sense if the list comprehension included the get_label_color call inside. Or perhaps just renaming color_labels to something like 'superlabels'.

content.raw: I'd reconsider naming this to 'extract_superlabel' or something similar to make it far more obvious what it does.
content.html: I'd reconsider naming this to 'extract_superlabel' or something similar to make it far more obvious what it does.

content.raw: Should probably put the last parameter on the next line for PEP-8 line length considerations
content.html: Should probably put the last parameter on the next line for PEP-8 line length considerations

content.raw: This is great and if I were to nitpick I'd specify what specifically the format of the label string you're expecting e.g. "%d.%d"
content.html: This is great and if I were to nitpick I'd specify what specifically the format of the label string you're expecting e.g. "%d.%d"

content.raw: Should probably split this across mulitple lines for the PEP 8 79 character limit.
content.html: Should probably split this across mulitple lines for the PEP 8 79 character limit.

content.raw: @ericr86 , does this solution look alright? Also, @hoffman, which file in the included docs would be best to mention the new user option and sublabel behavior?
content.html: @ericr86 , does this solution look alright? Also, @hoffman, which file in the included docs would be best to mention the new user option and sublabel behavior?

content.raw:
I think both solutions are fine.

An extract_label function might make things clearer. Also since you run the conditional on each item in the list you may want to consider using a map or list comprehension on the 'labels' list before or in the 'zip' but either way this is a much better solution so far.
content.html:
I think both solutions are fine.

An extract_label function might make things clearer. Also since you run the conditional on each item in the list you may want to consider using a map or list comprehension on the 'labels' list before or in the 'zip' but either way this is a much better solution so far.

content.raw:
Yeah that makes sense, although to allow double digit labels I might do it as
```
int(x.split(".")[0])
```
Since we still want to have the original labels in order to print out the full label for the variable 'name', would it be OK to have it as a conditional within the for loop, like

```
    for seg_start, seg_end, seg_label in zipper:
        name = str(seg_label)

        chrom_start = str(seg_start)
        chrom_end = str(seg_end)
        if isinstance(x, str):
          item_rgb = get_label_color(int(seg_label.split(".")[0]))
        else:
          item_rgb = get_label_color(seg_label)
```
It might be cleaner to have that be a separate function like extract_label also.
content.html:
Yeah that makes sense, although to allow double digit labels I might do it as

int(x.split(".")[0])

Since we still want to have the original labels in order to print out the full label for the variable 'name', would it be OK to have it as a conditional within the for loop, like

    for seg_start, seg_end, seg_label in zipper:
        name = str(seg_label)

        chrom_start = str(seg_start)
        chrom_end = str(seg_end)
        if isinstance(x, str):
          item_rgb = get_label_color(int(seg_label.split(".")[0]))
        else:
          item_rgb = get_label_color(seg_label)

It might be cleaner to have that be a separate function like extract_label also.

content.raw:
I think no matter what happens there should be a comment stating that the "label" list contains either integers or a string containing the label and sublabel.

It is also worth noting that for large values of sublabels this line will fails. For example the label/sublabel string "0.99999999999999999" will produce an integer output of 1. This is unrealistic but probably worth mentioning as well.

I'd consider running a list comprehension like shown below or use a map and a function to extract the integer label.
```python
[int(x[0]) if isinstance(x, str) else x for x in labels]
```
content.html:
I think no matter what happens there should be a comment stating that the "label" list contains either integers or a string containing the label and sublabel.

It is also worth noting that for large values of sublabels this line will fails. For example the label/sublabel string "0.99999999999999999" will produce an integer output of 1. This is unrealistic but probably worth mentioning as well.

I'd consider running a list comprehension like shown below or use a map and a function to extract the integer label.

[int(x[0]) if isinstance(x, str) else x for x in labels]

content.raw: Hey @ericr86 , can you look over this again, based on the tests (which still pass on my end) and Michael's comments (in the activity tab)? It prints out sublabels as it's supposed to, but I want to minimize changes to how segway actually runs if sublabels aren't being used.
content.html: Hey @ericr86 , can you look over this again, based on the tests (which still pass on my end) and Michael's comments (in the activity tab)? It prints out sublabels as it's supposed to, but I want to minimize changes to how segway actually runs if sublabels aren't being used.

content.raw: Not sure if there's a cleaner way to do this. At this point, seg_label is either an int (e.g. 0) or a string consisting of the label and sublabel (e.g. "0.1") if output_label is set to "full."
content.html: Not sure if there's a cleaner way to do this. At this point, seg_label is either an int (e.g. 0) or a string consisting of the label and sublabel (e.g. "0.1") if output_label is set to "full."

content.raw: Thanks for the comments, I'll make the suggested changes.
content.html: Thanks for the comments, I'll make the suggested changes.

content.raw: I've made some comments on this. This is a good start but there are various things that need to be improved to meet our code standards and good Python/NumPy coding practice.
content.html: I've made some comments on this. This is a good start but there are various things that need to be improved to meet our code standards and good Python/NumPy coding practice.

content.raw: Non-working code should go to another branch
content.html: Non-working code should go to another branch

content.raw: There should also be an early failure in run.py. Doing it here allows a user to get all the way through inference before they find out it won't work.
content.html: There should also be an early failure in run.py. Doing it here allows a user to get all the way through inference before they find out it won't work.

content.raw: Don't use floats when you don't have to.
content.html: Don't use floats when you don't have to.

content.raw: Please keep lines <79 characters. Run PEP8 on your code before pull request.
content.html: Please keep lines <79 characters. Run PEP8 on your code before pull request.

content.raw: This violates "Don't Repeat Yourself" a lot. When you are going to put this into an array eventually, good to do it earlier and do all the operations on the array rather than on individual variables.
content.html: This violates "Don't Repeat Yourself" a lot. When you are going to put this into an array eventually, good to do it earlier and do all the operations on the array rather than on individual variables.

content.raw: Again we need to make this more selective depending on what we actually want. Let's not collect lots of data we won't use unless "full" is being used.
content.html: Again we need to make this more selective depending on what we actually want. Let's not collect lots of data we won't use unless "full" is being used.

content.raw: This is not really descriptive. Also, you need to add this to the docs.
content.html: This is not really descriptive. Also, you need to add this to the docs.

content.raw: This looks like dead code. Is it used?
content.html: This looks like dead code. Is it used?

content.raw: output_label
content.html: output_label

content.raw: This needs to be more selective. Instead of using a global, `regex_filter` should change depending on output_label. Outputting everything that ends in `seg` will slow things down a lot.
content.html: This needs to be more selective. Instead of using a global, regex_filter should change depending on output_label. Outputting everything that ends in seg will slow things down a lot.

content.raw: No, `OUTPUT_LABEL`.
content.html: No, OUTPUT_LABEL.

content.raw: Don't use string concatenation in Python. Use string formatting operations (also will remove need to find and call `str()` twice within the loop, to do tuple unpacking and so on). Also don't use variable names like `x` and `y`. Also, you should be able to access all of `data[,start_pos]` from the start rather than subsetting twice.
content.html: Don't use string concatenation in Python. Use string formatting operations (also will remove need to find and call str() twice within the loop, to do tuple unpacking and so on). Also don't use variable names like x and y. Also, you should be able to access all of data[,start_pos] from the start rather than subsetting twice.

content.raw: I was just going with the naming scheme of num-labels option -> num_segs variable. I can change that.
content.html: I was just going with the naming scheme of num-labels option -> num_segs variable. I can change that.

content.raw: If you aren't fixing posterior code here, all this stuff should go to some other branch.
content.html: If you aren't fixing posterior code here, all this stuff should go to some other branch.
